abstract.t:
hashtagbibs (or simply: 'bibs') are tiny tags, allowing mere mortals to connect words to other words using pencil, voice or keyboard.
They allow polyglot tagging by expanding into multiple (reversed) BibTags, JSON or XML snippets.

For example, using OCR, scanned paper can now easily 'connect' with online graphs.
Think of it as the brother of hashtags: a command for tagging-this-with-that.
The goal of this spec is three-fold:

ul.li: specify bibs: a plaintext tagging DSL which expands into various languages
specify bibs as URI fragment: a way to hint browsers to filter a document on certain tag(s)
specify bibrulers: to specify bibtags microformats like visual-meta

section.name: What are bibs
section.t: bibs allow non-technical humans to write (reversed) BibTags, JSON or XML, in a short-form (on paper):
section.artwork:
John please get out the laundry
#john #laundry@chores@todo

ul.li: tag laundry with tagname chores and todo

section.t: and expands into the following formats:

blockquote.t: the word and john laundry can now be highlighted in the human text (or 3D object can be shown when their objectname matches). bibs are basically one step up from socialmedia hashtags, allowing mere mortals to connect words to other things using pencil, voice or keyboard.

section.t: There's no precise predicates or properties, just simply 'this points to that', which empowers citizen annotation (an essential precursor of RDF).

blockquote.t: NOTE: in the rest of this article, we use focus on BibTex for convenience (as it is the most terse, easiest to write/repair/speak outputformat).

section.name: format

blockquote.t: syntactically, bibs are hashtags with (concatenated) emaildomains without an extension

ol.li: to qualify as a bib, a word should start with a hashtag, and (optionally) contain on or more @ characters
last bib wins: overlapping bibs overwrite eachother (last tag(s) win)
spaces are not allowed, maximum by using + to represents spaces (the+bill@todo e.g.)

section.name: hashtagbib mimetypes
section.t: This mimetype indicates that bibs and their expanded format occuring in plain text, are automatically hidden and expanded by browsers.

blockquote.t: For example bib=^@ means that lines matching regex ^@ (BibTex) will automatically get filtered out, in order for software to:

ul.li: automatically create/detect links between textual/spatial objects within the document (see XR Fragments)

blockquote.t: This significantly expands expressiveness and portability of human tagged text, by postponing machine-concerns to the end of the human text in contrast to literal interweaving of content and markupsymbols (like markdown/HTML/XML/JSON etc)

section.name: Example: an textual kanban using tags
section.artwork:
buy milk finish paper contact John buy the great gatsby
#milk@todo #contact@doing #contact@done #gatsby@done #finish+paper@doing

section.name: Bibs & BibTeX combo: lowest common denominator for linking data
section.t: Eventhough Bibs can expand to JSON and XML as well, it's worth noting that Bibs & BibTex are closest to human thought:

Unlike XML or JSON, BibTex is typeless, unnested, and uncomplicated, hence a great advantage for introspection.
It's a missing, lowbarrier, sensemaking precursor to extrospective RDF.

blockquote.t: "When a car breaks down, the ones without turbosupercharger are easier to fix"

section.t:
BibTeX-appendices are already used in the digital AND physical world (academic books, visual-meta), perhaps due to its terseness & simplicity.
In that sense, it's one step up from the .ini fileformat (which has never leaked into the physical world like BibTex):

ol.li: frictionless copy/pasting (by humans) of (unobtrusive) content AND metadata
an introspective 'sketchpad' for metadata, which can (optionally) mature into RDF later

section.name: Merging (BibTagged) overlaps
section.t: When a bib (#great+gatsby@book is copy-pasted into another document (a PDF or Textfile with a visual-meta appendix e.g.):

ol.li: the editor should check for the existence of @book{great+gatsby
if exist: do nothing, leave target document as is
if not: create the expanded BibTag
optionally, the editor can offer to add properties (as bibs are propertyless)

blockquote.t: propertyless bibs, are a great way as a 'process later'-medium ("I wrote down great+gatsby@readinglist on a papertowel/email, to scan/copy-paste it later)

section.t: The following allows for microformats:

section.t: expands into the following:
BibTex rulers have been pioneered by the visual-meta microformat as a means of organizing BibTags:
Eventhough it looks like 'nested data', this snippet would actually get decoded to this unnested array:

Why not a nested tree-structure? This kneejerk reaction should always be considered 'a temporary option'.
Don't forget that Bibrulers are simply rulers (not blocks):

ol.li: don't try to re-invent XML or JSON
don't promote traversing graphs (instead: just a list with tags)
they promote rather dumb, unnested, streamable lists (unlike HTML/XML/JSON) adhering to JSONLines/CSV
they are much faster/simpler to lookup, implement, (de)serialize across low- and highlevel languages.
